text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This IRM has been revised throughout to provide clariﬁcations and more in-depth discussions in several areas. Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary. Signiﬁcant to this IRM are reﬂected in the table below:

IRM Reference Description of Change All Update ownership of IRM 4.16.1 from Abusive Transactions–Technical Issues to SB/SE Examination–Field and Campus Policy, Field Examination Special Processes (FESP). IRM 4.16.1.3.2.2 Deleted redundant information already contained in IRM 4.10.3.3.6. IRM 4.16.1.3.4 Updated information about when to consider a summons and to consult with Counsel for enforcement information. IRM 4.16.1.3.5 Updated the list of indirect methods. IRM 4.16.1.3.7 Guidance added regarding group managers on the 6 (e) list for grand jury cases and tainted civil closings. IRM 4.16.1.4.1 Updated information on the SEP Information Referral process. IRM 4.16.1.4.2 Updated Sources for Obtaining Leads listing. IRM 4.16.1.5.2 Updated source code listing for SEP inventory. IRM 4.16.1.5.4 Updated project code listing for SEP inventory. IRM 4.16.1.5.5 Updated activity code listing for SEP inventory. IRM 4.16.1.5.6 Updated aging reason code listing for SEP inventory. IRM 4.16.1.6.1 Removed outdated DEA agreements from the background information. IRM 4.16.1.6.2 Removed obsolete SEP categories and references to DOJ Strike Force. Former IRM 4.16.1.7 Deleted Management Responsibilities for Strike Force Activity. SEP does not actively participate on Strike Force teams. CI has comprehensive Strike Force information in IRM 9.4.13.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 4.16.1, dated June 14, 2011.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
and Case Development

) This chapter provides an overview and outlines the purpose and goals of Special Enforcement Program (SEP). SEP is a specialized compliance program within the Small Business/Self-Employed Operating Division directed toward that segment of the population which derives substantial income from either legal or illegal activities and intentionally understate their tax liability. (

) SEP evolved from a “Strike Force”, program focused on organized crime illegal activity into a compliance program with emphasis on identifying, oping and investigating fraudulent income and expense issues of both legal and illegal entities. (

) The goal of SEP is to enhance voluntary compliance and to promote public conﬁdence in the tax system. This maximum deterrence is generated by examining those cases which signiﬁcantly impact the public and assisting in the investigation and prosecution of prominent or notorious individuals who attempt to evade or defeat the tax system. (
) SEP cases normally involve in-depth income examinations. IRC

(e), tation on examination on unreported income, of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) states that the Service is not to use ﬁnancial status or economic examination techniques, such as indirect methods, to determine the income of any taxpayer unless there is a reasonable indication that there is likelihood of such unreported income. (

) The examination of income is a mandatory audit issue. The depth of the ex- amination of income and the types of investigative techniques used are dependent on the facts and circumstances of the case. To determine unreported income exists, the SEP agent should: conduct the minimum probes; resolve Large, Unusual and Questionable (LUQ) income items; perform a ﬁnancial status analysis; and evaluate internal controls in the case a business return. If the likelihood of unreported income has been the use of Financial Status Audit Techniques (FSAT) would be appropriate are not prohibited by IRC

) If the SEP agent has established that there is a reasonable likelihood of ported income, a more in-depth examination of income is warranted. Any technique or procedure used to determine the amount of unreported income could be labeled a FSAT. A FSAT is, therefore, deﬁned by its purpose which a technique, analysis or procedure used to determine the speciﬁc amount of unreported income. See IRM
, In-Depth Examinations of Income: dividual Taxpayer. (

) In some instances the SEP agent may have reasonable indications that the likelihood of unreported income exists prior to the start of the actual tion. Examples of such sources could include: information from informants/ whistleblowers; Criminal Investigation (CI); federal, state or local law ment; or Information Reporting Program (IRP). (

) The SEP agent should document in workpapers the sources of information/ evidence secured, the analysis of the information/evidence and the conclusions–and also document the dates those events and actions This step should always take place regardless of the methods used or the formation made available to reach the determination that the likelihood of unreported income exists. Internal Revenue Manual
SEP Responsibilities and Case Development

) This chapter provides an overview and outlines the purpose and goals of Special Enforcement Program (SEP). SEP is a specialized compliance program within the Small Business/Self-Employed Operating Division directed toward that segment of the population which derives substantial income from either legal or illegal activities and intentionally understate their tax liability. (

) SEP evolved from a “Strike Force”, program focused on organized crime illegal activity into a compliance program with emphasis on identifying, oping and investigating fraudulent income and expense issues of both legal and illegal entities. (

) The goal of SEP is to enhance voluntary compliance and to promote public conﬁdence in the tax system. This maximum deterrence is generated by examining those cases which signiﬁcantly impact the public and assisting in the investigation and prosecution of prominent or notorious individuals who attempt to evade or defeat the tax system. (
) SEP cases normally involve in-depth income examinations. IRC

(e), tation on examination on unreported income, of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) states that the Service is not to use ﬁnancial status or economic examination techniques, such as indirect methods, to determine the income of any taxpayer unless there is a reasonable indication that there is likelihood of such unreported income. (

) The examination of income is a mandatory audit issue. The depth of the ex- amination of income and the types of investigative techniques used are dependent on the facts and circumstances of the case. To determine unreported income exists, the SEP agent should: conduct the minimum probes; resolve Large, Unusual and Questionable (LUQ) income items; perform a ﬁnancial status analysis; and evaluate internal controls in the case a business return. If the likelihood of unreported income has been the use of Financial Status Audit Techniques (FSAT) would be appropriate

SEP cases normally involve in-depth income examinations. IRC 7602(e), Limi- tation on examination on unreported income, of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) states that the Service is not to use ﬁnancial status or economic reality examination techniques, such as indirect methods, to determine the unreported income of any taxpayer unless there is a reasonable indication that there is a likelihood of such unreported income.
Special Enforcement Program (

) The core roles and responsibilities of SEP examiners are to: a. Identify and develop those issues, which have signiﬁcant fraud through the examination of complex ﬁnancial transactions. b. Assist in ﬁnancial investigations of taxpayers who derive legal and income, but choose to evade their tax liability through one or more tions of the tax law. c. Serve as the cooperating agent in administrative and grand jury tions. d. Provide trial assistance as expert and/or summary witness in criminal prosecutions. e. Assist Area Counsel in trial preparation. f. Protect the Government’s interest through the use of jeopardy and/or mination assessments. g. Ensure the civil disposition of closed criminal prosecutions. (

) The objectives of SEP are to: a. Perform timely and effectively planned and managed examinations of returns ﬁled notwithstanding obstacles created by complexity, tion, scarcity of audit records and evidence, difficulty in securing records and testimony or geographic dispersion of operations. b. Accumulate at the Headquarters’ level and disseminate novel techniques, issues unique to legal or illegal income sources, avoidance and evasion schemes, and all other information useful in planning and executing examinations. c. Encourage and promote communications and exchange of techniques procedures between compliance officers as an aid in achieving the effective examination. (

) Elements of SEP cases include, but are not limited to: a. Unreported income b. False expenses/credits c. Abusive return preparers d. Frivolous ﬁlers/non-ﬁlers e. Abusive trusts/abusive trust schemes f. Tax Shelters g. Fraudulent specialty tax investigations (for example, Employment Tax and/or Excise Tax Investigations) h. Health care fraud i. Racketeering/organized crime j. Narcotic trafficking k. Illegal gambling operations l. Prostitution m. Pornography n. Embezzlement and theft o. Political corruption p. Credit card fraud q. Bank fraud r. Currency violations (Fi
EN/SAR) s. Offshore activities t. Internet fraud u. Compliance Initiative Projects (CIP) v. Whistleblower cases w. Promoter Investigations
4.16 Special Enforcement Program
Elements of SEP cases include, but are not limited to:
Responsibilities and Case Development 4.16.1
y. Identity Theft (

) Revenue Agents in SEP are ﬁnancial investigative specialists and forensic countants. In addition to general tax law knowledge and auditing skills, and agents are experts in the identiﬁcation and development of cases with potential. (

) SEP agents: a. Identify fraud issues and recognize indicators of fraudulent activity. b. Conduct in-depth examinations of cases with fraud potential. c. Conduct detailed interviews of taxpayers and third party witnesses. d. Secure evidence, with a summons if necessary, to determine taxable income. e. Submit referrals to CI on cases meeting criminal criteria. f. Participate as a tax law expert in joint investigations and assist in computing the criminal tax liability. g. Balance civil and criminal aspects in joint investigation cases, including protection of the statute of limitations. h. Prepare examination reports, compute tax liability and propose civil penalties. i. Act as technical advisor and assist the U. S. Attorney’s office with jury investigations. j. Assist U. S. Attorney’s office and Area Counsel in preparing tax tions and special schedules for judicial purposes. k. Testify as an expert or summary witness in criminal and civil tax trials. l. Develop leads by networking with local, state and federal agencies. (

) SEP agents who serve as the Subject Matter Experts (SME) are resource persons for SB/SE Examination and other Service functions in the areas: a. Indirect methods of reconstructing income. b. Preparation, use and enforcement of summonses, IRM
, Handbook. c. Effective interviewing techniques and documentation. d. Development and application of civil fraud penalty, IRC
, and lent failure to ﬁle penalty, IRC
(f). See IRM
, Civil Fraud, IRM
, Penalty Handbook. e. Recommendation of jeopardy and termination assessments. See IRM

, Jeopardy and Terminations. f. Expert witness and trial preparation. g. Accumulation and dissemination of novel examination techniques to income tax examinations and tax evasion schemes. h. Provision of face-to-face and virtual learning on topics such as auditing income, investigative techniques, and management of administrative investigations as well as grand jury investigations with IRS-CI. (

) An in-depth interview is one of the most important aspects of a SEP tion. Interviews are used to obtain leads, develop information and establish evidence. The testimony of witnesses and the admissions of alleged are major factors in resolving tax cases. (

An in
depth interview is one of the most important aspects of a SEP examina
tion. Interviews are used to obtain leads, develop information and establish evidence. The testimony of witnesses and the admissions of alleged violators are major factors in resolving tax cases.
Special Enforcement Program (
) In an initial interview, the SEP agent should obtain as much information as possible to evaluate the taxpayer’s complete ﬁnancial situation, since this be the only contact with the taxpayer. (
) SEP agents should interview the taxpayer and every pertinent witness connected with the case. See IRM
, Who To Interview. (
) As additional information and facts are uncovered, follow-up interviews may critical to issue development. The use of a Summons to secure testimony should be considered as appropriate. (

) Interviewing taxpayers in custody: a. Before interviewing a taxpayer conﬁned in prison or otherwise detained federal, state or local authorities, the SEP agent will ﬁrst evaluate the for fraud potential. b. If the case has no fraud potential, the SEP agent may conduct the interview without the assistance of a Special Agent (SA). c. If the case has ﬁrm indications of criminal fraud, the SEP agent will the case to CI without interviewing the taxpayer in custody. d. If the evaluation of fraud potential is not possible without interviewing taxpayer in custody, the SEP agent will prepare a memorandum to the Special Agent in Charge (SAC), CI. This memorandum will request the assignment of a SA to assist in the interview and to inform the taxpayer custody of their constitutional rights in accordance with the decision of Miranda v. Arizona,
S. Ct.

). e. After the interview, the assigned SA may assist the SEP agent in ing any possible fraud implications. If ﬁrm indications of criminal fraud not present, the SEP agent will continue to work the case. f. It is not necessary for a SA to be present when interviewing a third witness in custody. (

) The SEP agent must prepare a permanent record of every interview using or more of the following: a. Memorandum of interview; b. Transcript of interview or Question and Answer Statement; c. Affidavit; or d. Audio recording. (
) Interviews of members of a federally recognized Indian tribe should be in cordance with protocols set forth by relevant Presidential Executive Orders. See IRM
, Cases Requiring Special Handling. (
) One of the principal responsibilities of a SEP agent is to obtain early and accurate information. (

) SEP agents must initiate and proceed with in-depth examinations on the as- sumption that cases will result in litigation. It is, therefore, incumbent upon SEP agent to obtain as much testimonial and documentary evidence as possible. (

) During the examination, the SEP agent may obtain oral testimony which signiﬁcantly affect the outcome of the case. The SEP agent should have the individual attest to the accuracy of their statements by preparing and signing an affidavit or statement. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M
4.16 Special Enforcement Program (SEP)
and Case Development
page (

) The average individual is not familiar with the law, therefore, the SEP agent should advise them that preparing or giving a false statement is a criminal offense. Therefore, an attested statement has greater validity when properly prepared and voluntarily given. (

) Affidavits and statements are used to: a. Record the testimony of a witness; b. Refresh the memory of a witness; c. Deter a witness from becoming hostile and changing their testimony; d. Impeach a hostile witness; e. Be used as evidence; and/or f. Help accumulate complete and accurate information. (
) SEP Agents may use some of the following methods to record statements: a. Affidavit—See IRM

, Affidavit. b. Narrative Affidavit—Primarily is used by SEP agents. Variations are accepted as long as the basic elements remain unchanged. If feasible, subject should be requested to examine, make corrections and sign the document. If they refuse to sign, the following legend should be inserted the end of the statement: “This statement was read by [subject’s name] [date], who stated that it is true and correct, but refused to sign it.” c. Summarized Narrative—A summary of a conversation or statement by a taxpayer or witness who should be requested to examine, make rections and sign the document. The SEP agents present at the should always sign the statement. d. Question and Answer—The witness should attest to its accuracy. e. Reports of Interview—A summary of an interview that is not signed by taxpayer or witness, but attested to by the SEP agent. (

) The SEP agent may decide to administer an oath to the taxpayer and/or witness at the start of the interview. The authority to administer oaths and mations, whether pursuant to the issuance of a summons or a request for information, is in IRC
, Examination of books and witnesses and IRC

, Authority to administer oaths and certify. While CI may normally ter oaths on a regular basis, it is recommended that SEP agents seek Area Counsel guidance prior to the creation of an oath to record statements. For additional information on oaths and the waiver of constitutional rights, see
, Waiver of Constitutional Rights, and related exhibits. (
) Requests to make audio tape, audio disk, stenographic or other verbatim re- cordings of interviews will ordinarily be allowed except where the taxpayer or representative’s behavior is disruptive. (

) Recording an interview of a taxpayer or witness should be considered when the SEP agent has concerns that testimony may later change. The Service record an interview of a taxpayer or witness. In instances where the Service initiates the recording, the interview does not have to occur at an IRS office. (
) For comprehensive information on the recording of interviews, see IRM
, Requests to Audio Record Interviews. Internal Revenue Manual
Responsibilities and Case Development 4.16.1
Special Enforcement Program (

) SEP examinations are unique because of the signiﬁcant potential for fraud litigation. Many SEP cases result in recommendations for criminal and an even greater number involve assertions of the civil fraud penalty. (

) The nature of SEP cases increases the likelihood that the burden of proof rest with the government. SEP agents must gather the evidence necessary sufficiently substantiate and prove the facts of the case. (
) SEP agents should be familiar with the Federal Rules of Evidence (FRE) ticularly: a. Best evidence rule (FRE
, Deﬁnitions That Apply to This Article through
, Summaries to prove content); b. Hearsay rule and exceptions (FRE
, Deﬁnitions That Apply to This Article; Exclusions from Hearsay through
, Attacking and the Declarant); and c. Attorney client and accountant client privilege rules (FRE
, Privilege General). (
) SEP agents should also be familiar with case law interpretations of principles and the law of privileges, such as the attorney-client privilege the practitioner privileges of IRC
, Conﬁdentiality privileges relating to taxpayer communications. See IRM
, Conﬁdentiality Privileges Relating to Taxpayer Communications—Accountant/Client Privilege and
, Summonses. (
) When securing evidence, SEP agents must always be aware of the provisions of Rule
of the Rules of Federal Criminal Procedure. SEP must always verify that the information received was not grand jury tion. (
) SEP agents can utilize evidence secured by federal, state or local law ment agencies in securing leads and developing cases. Warrant Secured (
) SEP agents should obtain a copy of the search warrant and/or inventory to document how the evidence was obtained. (
) Consult Area Counsel if there is a motion to suppress the search warrant other technical problems with the search warrant evidence. In U.S. v. Janis,
USTC
U.S.
S. Ct.
, the Service was allowed use evidence for civil purposes that was suppressed from criminal usage the local authorities. (

) Evidence developed from a court ordered electronic monitoring can be an important source of information in SEP cases. The evidence may support a computation of income for a period of time in cases such as wagering or narcotics as well as links to assets, expenditures, associates of a taxpayer (Wire Tap) other leads. Generally, the evidence will consist of tapes of actual conversations, listing of telephone numbers called (Pen Register) and from which calls were received (Trap and Trace). (
) Title
U.S. Code section
, Authorization for disclosure and use of cepted wire, oral, or electronic communications, sets forth a statutory under which disclosure and use of intercepted oral and wire are permitted. Section
) permits law enforcement officers who obtain Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Title 18 U.S. Code section 2517, Authorization for disclosure and use of inter- cepted wire, oral, or electronic communications, sets forth a statutory theme under which disclosure and use of intercepted oral and wire communications are permitted. Section 2517(1) permits law enforcement officers who obtain
Responsibilities and Case Development 4.16.1
Caution: Title
U.S. Code section

, Prohibition of use as evidence of cepted wire or oral communications prohibits the use of evidence from intercepted wire communications, if that information is in violation the law. Before receiving such evidence, SEP agents must obtain the subsequent court order releasing the evidence to the IRS for use in an income tax examination. Follow the procedures set forth below to preserve the IRS’s right to use this evidence. (

) The SEP agent is responsible for initiating an application for disclosure. On U.S. District Court approved case the application should be made through Counsel to the U.S. Attorney’s office. On a state court approved case, the plication will be made through Area Counsel to either the District Attorney’s office or the U.S. Attorney’s office. When the order is obtained through the District Attorney’s office, the ﬁnal order should be forwarded to Area Counsel after receipt for its approval of the order. (

) Once approval of the court and/or Area Counsel is secured, the SEP agent make arrangements for a SA to be assigned to accompany the SEP agent secure the evidence. The SA will make a determination about the criminal aspects of the evidence received. If none is found or prosecution is declined due to dual prosecution or other reasons, the SA will refer the evidence to SEP agent for civil purposes. (
) Disclosure by the SEP agent should be limited to those named on the order. Title
U.S. Code section
) allows disclosure of such evidence while giving testimony under oath in any proceeding held under the authority of United States. (

) When closing an unagreed case, the electronic communications evidence be removed from the case ﬁle and stored in a secured access storage area within an IRS office to prevent unauthorized disclosure. The workpapers indicate that additional evidence is under the control of the SEP agent and would be available for litigation. On an unagreed case, the evidence should held in the secured area until the statutes for any claims have expired at time the evidence should be destroyed. (
) See Chief Counsel Directives Manual (CCDM)
dated June
for further information on electronic surveillance. (

) The summons is an important tool for obtaining the records and testimony needed to complete in-depth examinations. SEP cases frequently involve cooperative taxpayers who do not agree to be interviewed or provide records to which they have access or control. When lack of cooperation occurs, serious consideration should be given to summonsing the taxpayer relevant testimony and records. Third party summonses should also be used obtain necessary testimony and records.

Before receiving such evidence, SEP agents must obtain the subsequent court order releasing the evidence to the IRS for use in an income tax examination. Follow the procedures set forth below to preserve the IRS’s right to use this evidence.
4.16 Special Enforcement Program (SEP)

) SEP agents should be familiar with provisions of the law relating to the use and enforcement of a summons. SEP agents should use good judgment considering the issuance of a summons. Consult with SBSE Counsel for guidance speciﬁc to your individual case. (
) A summons should be prepared and issued in accordance with the IRM Summons Handbook. (

) SEP cases often involve taxpayers who do not maintain adequate books records. Therefore, SEP agents must be well versed in the various and reconstructing income. The two basic approaches in determining correct taxable income are: a. Speciﬁc item method; and b. Indirect method. (

) The speciﬁc item method uses speciﬁc items to identify unreported income from both legal and illegal sources. This preferred method limits the ability to challenge the government’s determination since this method is on information personal to the taxpayer. (
) When speciﬁc items are not traceable, it may be necessary to use indirect methods to reconstruct income based on circumstantial evidence. The use indirect methods is allowed by IRC
, General rule for methods of ing, and has been upheld by the courts in civil and criminal tax cases. (

) The court tested methods of reconstructing income include: a. Bank deposits and cash expenditures; b. Expenditures method (commonly known as Source and Application of Funds); c. Net worth; d. Percentage mark-up; e. Unit and Volume. (

) The indirect method used must include evidence of a likely source of income. In addition, the SEP agent must always address and refute defenses such as nontaxable sources of income and cash hoard whether the taxpayer raised such defenses. (
) IRM
, Formal Indirect Methods of Determining Income, provides guidance on the use of various indirect methods. (
) SEP agents devote a signiﬁcant amount of time working joint investigations with CI. Joint investigations are also known as administrative tax cases. (

) Joint investigations are comprehensive investigations conducted jointly by and Examination. The primary purpose of a joint investigation is to criminal tax fraud is involved and whether criminal prosecution should be ommended. In addition to assisting with the criminal tax computation, SEP agents are responsible for the civil aspects of the case including, but not limited to, the following: • Statute protection (see IRM
, Statute Protection) • Consideration of subsequent year and related returns Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M
SEP agents devote a signiﬁcant amount of time working joint investigations with CI. Joint investigations are also known as administrative tax cases.
Statute protection (see IRM 25.1.4.3.8, Statute Protection) Consideration of subsequent year and related returns
and Case Development
page • Preparation of the Revenue Agent workpapers and examination report of adjustments for prosecution and non-prosecution years • Civil closing. (
) Joint investigations can originate from the following: a. Form
, Referral Report of Potential Criminal Fraud Cases or b. Form
, Request for Cooperating Examiner. (

) Upon assignment, the SEP agent should verify that the case is an tive tax case rather than a grand jury case. Different procedures apply for grand jury cases as explained in the following section. (

) SEP agents and SA’s have separate, clearly deﬁned roles in joint investiga- tions. SEP agents must not participate in law enforcement activities nor be placed in situations for which they are not trained and/or which may put them or others at risk. (
) SEP agent responsibilities and detailed procedures regarding joint investiga- tions can be found in IRM
, Administrative Joint Investigation. (

) A grand jury is a powerful investigative tool for the government used to gate allegations of criminal wrongdoing. SEP agents are frequently involved with grand jury investigations and grand jury material. (
) Proceedings of a grand jury are secret and are governed by Rule
(e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The use of grand jury information for purposes is further restricted by the decisions in United States v. Baggot, S. Ct.
) and United States v. Sells Engineering Co., Inc.,
S.
) The group manager (GM) of an agent assigned to a grand jury case should request they be added to the grand jury access list (

(e) list) in order to tively participate in discussions involving case actions and provide feedback. The GM should evaluate the employee on current assignments, manage workload and balance grand jury inventory. (

) The SEP agent assigned to a grand jury assists the U.S. Attorney’s office, which controls the investigation. The SEP agent is primarily concerned with consideration, resolution and review of issues as they relate to the criminal charges being investigated. (

) Although the SEP agent involved in the grand jury case will not complete the ﬁnal civil tax liability, they must be aware of the civil ramiﬁcations of received or developed during the grand jury investigation. Only information made a matter of public record or obtained prior to or independent of the jury can be used in a subsequent civil case. (
) SEP agents may use their credentials for identiﬁcation, but must make it that they are assisting in a grand jury investigation as a grand jury agent. (
) IRS summonses are not used in a grand jury investigation. Documents and testimony are obtained by the U.S. Attorney’s office through the use of grand jury subpoenas.
Responsibilities and Case Development 4.16.1
SEP agent responsibilities and detailed procedures regarding joint investiga- tions can be found in IRM 25.1.4, Administrative Joint Investigation.
agents may use their credentials for identiﬁcation, but must make it clear they are assisting in a grand jury investigation as a grand jury agent.
Special Enforcement Program (
) The grand jury SEP agent is considered tainted and is prohibited from pating in any civil aspects of the case resulting from the grand jury. on a
(e) list are also considered tainted and must refer the civil closing to another group. (
) Guidance for grand jury investigations can be found in IRM
, Grand Investigations. (

) SEP agents often assist and/or testify in civil and criminal court proceedings. Examples include: and Trial a. Criminal tax trials; b. Tax court cases; c. Grand jury proceedings; d. Bankruptcy hearings; e. Summons enforcement hearings; and f. Judicial reviews of jeopardy and termination assessment cases. (
) SEP agent responsibilities will vary depending on the issues of the case. government attorney will determine the role of the SEP agent. (
) Government prosecution cases require extensive time for preparation and SEP agents should be prepared to spend any additional time necessary to assist the government attorney in the case. (
) The SEP agent should contact the local Disclosure Office to determine a testimony authorization is required pursuant to
CFR
See
, Delegation Order
(Rev.
) (formerly DO-
). In general, a testimony authorization is not required in a case referred by the Service to government where the government is calling the SEP agent as a witness. (
) The most common duty as a SEP agent in courtroom proceedings is during a criminal trial as an expert witness or as a summary witness. (
) An expert witness is a person skilled in some area or who has experience or knowledge not generally known to ordinary persons (Federal Rules of Evidence, Rule
). Under Rule
(e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the defense can ask for the witness’s qualiﬁcations. It is that SEP agents maintain all professional requirements and a current (

) Once qualiﬁed before the court, the expert witness is called upon to express an opinion based on facts presumably in the record of the case. The expert witness reviews the government’s evidence and expresses an opinion as to the issue needing expert assistance. Generally, the expert witness is called testify immediately prior to the government’s ﬁnal witness and is excluded hearing testimony during the trial. (

) A summary witness listens to all evidence presented during the trial and is ﬁnal witness called in the government’s case to convince the jury there was harm to the government. A summary witness will be qualiﬁed as an expert in federal income tax computations. Generally, the summary witness is a SEP agent or a compliance officer with no prior involvement in the investigation. (
) Occasionally, SEP agents will be used as both the expert witness and the summary witness. In this situation, the SEP agent renders an expert opinion and prepares the tax computation.
4.16 Special Enforcement Program (SEP)
SEP agent responsibilities will vary depending on the issues of the case. government attorney will determine the role of the SEP agent.

The SEP agent should contact the local Disclosure Office to determine whether a testimony authorization is required pursuant to 26 CFR 301.9000-1. See IRM 1.2.49.3, Delegation Order 11-2 (Rev. 2) (formerly DO-11-2). In general, a testimony authorization is not required in a case referred by the Service to the government where the government is calling the SEP agent as a witness.
The most common duty as a SEP agent in courtroom proceedings is testifying during a criminal trial as an expert witness or as a summary witness.
Responsibilities and Case Development 4.16.1

) SEP agents may obtain information during an income tax investigation ing that non-tax criminal violations have occurred or may witness criminal falling under the jurisdiction of another federal agency. When obtaining information from outside sources, SEP agents must follow third party contact procedures in accordance with IRC 7602(c), Notice of contact of third parties, and IRM 4.10.3.3.1.4, Third Party Interviews.
Special Enforcement Program (
) Before making a third party contact, SEP agents must determine which advance notiﬁcation letter is appropriate. Because of the nature of their SEP agents are authorized to use Letter
-E, (Exam-
) Third Party Contact, letter except for non-ﬁlers. See IRM
, Third Party Contact Program. (

) Contact with the Service, initiated by a third party such as a member of law enforcement or an informant, is not considered a third party contact. if the SEP agent contacts a third party regarding a speciﬁc taxpayer, the contact requires advance notiﬁcation to the taxpayer and a recordation of contact. (

) Advance taxpayer notiﬁcation requirements do not apply when: a. The taxpayer authorizes the third party contact; b. Such notice would jeopardize collection of any tax; or c. There is a pending criminal investigation. (
) In jeopardy/termination assessment cases no advance notiﬁcation is However, Form

, Third Party Contact Report Form, must be prepared each contact and submitted to the Third Party Coordinator when the situation no longer exists. If additional contacts will be made, the SEP will also prepare and send the appropriate Letter
if one has not been provided to the taxpayer. (

) Advance notiﬁcation requirements do not apply when the third party has a reprisal concern. Therefore, it is important to make a reprisal determination during the initial contact with third parties. Form
, is submitted with reprisal block marked rather than listing the name of the third party. (
) Advance notiﬁcation requirements do not apply to any general, primary, criminal or subject seizure investigation initiated by CI. Form
, is not required in these cases. (
) For additional guidance, see IRM
, Interviews: Authority and See IRM
, Third Party Contacts. (
) The following overview should be used in conjunction with the material in the AIMS portion of the IRM. (
) This section identiﬁes the various source codes, status codes, activity and project codes unique to SEP. (
) Source Code
(Special Enforcement) is used to request returns and/or control on case(s) involving illegal activity. (
) Source Code
(Special Enforcement Related Pick-ups) is used to request multi-year or related return and or AIMS control on case(s) involving illegal activity. (
) Source Code

(Fraud Regular) is used to request returns and AIMS/or control on case(s) for a joint investigation or for the purpose of referring returns to CI. In general, returns already open on AIMS with another source code should not be updated to Source Code

) SEP work includes legal source income, however, initially SEP was directed only toward illegal income sources. The following subsections provides a ground on initial source of SEP work. (

) SEP is directed toward that segment of the public who derives substantial income from illegal activities. The very nature of these illegal activities close cooperation with the Department of Justice (DOJ) and other federal, state and local law enforcement agencies. (

) The DOJ agreement established guidelines which were compatible with the Service’s policy of fair and effective administration and enforcement of tax and the objective of DOJ to give priority to the investigations and prosecution of organized criminal activity, corruption in government, narcotics trafficking, and all forms of white-collar crimes. Provisions were also made for continued cooperation between the Service and DOJ on Strike Force matters. The document also established a Coordinating Committee to resolve any ments that may arise. (

) IRS Racketeer—A taxpayer identiﬁed as being engaged in organized crime activities; notorious or powerful with respect to local criminal activities; receiving substantial income from illegal activities as a principal, a major dinate, or an important aider or abettor; or inﬁltrating legitimate businesses through illegal means or through loaning or investing therein the proceeds illegal activities. (
) Wagering—Taxpayers engaged in an occupation requiring registration or one who is engaged in receiving wagers. (

) Illegal Income—Includes any person who is reasonably believed to be receiving substantial income from an illegal activity that is separate and apart from the alleged tax violations, such as corruption in government, welfare or commercial bribery.
